dialog.text: I’m torn—what’s the difference between storywriting and journaling?
dialog.instructions: tone: curious; pace: moderate; emotion: intimate; emphasis: contrast between two practices

dialog.text: Storywriting shapes a moment into a world with arc; journaling records the moment as it is.
dialog.instructions: tone: explanatory; pace: steady; emphasis: 'arc' and 'records'

dialog.text: So journaling is raw truth; stories are crafted meaning.
dialog.instructions: tone: declarative; pace: even; emphasis: 'raw truth' vs 'crafted meaning'

dialog.text: Exactly. Journaling keeps you honest; storytelling gives your truth a voice others can hear.
dialog.instructions: tone: affirming; pace: calm; emphasis: 'honest' and 'voice others can hear'

dialog.text: Think of a rainy bus ride: journaling logs the ride; storytelling turns it into a lesson.
dialog.instructions: tone: illustrative; pace: a touch slower; imagery: rain, bus ride

dialog.text: Both tools serve the same goal: understand yourself and connect with others.
dialog.instructions: tone: wise; pace: gentle; emphasis: 'same goal'

dialog.text: Want a quick experiment? journal for a week, then write a micro-story from the same moment, and share what you learned in the comments.
dialog.instructions: tone: encouraging; pace: brisk; call to action at end
